etymologies: Old English, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zuster and German Schwester, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin soror

definitions: a woman or girl in relation to other daughters and sons of her parents

examples.text: I had nine brothers and sisters

shortDefinitions: woman or girl in relation to other daughters and sons of her parents

definitions: a close female friend or associate, especially a female fellow member of a labor union or other organization

examples.text: textile unions are showing solidarity with their brothers and sisters in the developing world

definitions: a fellow woman seen in relation to feminist issues
shortDefinitions: fellow woman seen in relation to feminist issues

definitions: a black woman (chiefly used as a term of address by other black people)

examples.text: “Come on, sister, why not come clean and tell us?”

definitions: a member of a religious order or congregation of women

examples.text: the sisters announced that there would be a special rosary every morning
Sister Elizabeth, the headmistress of the Convent High School

shortDefinitions: member of religious order of women

definitions: a senior female nurse, typically in charge of a ward

examples.text: the ward sister needs to be consulted
Sister nodded, glancing at the reports

definitions: denoting an organization or place that bears a relationship to another of common origin or allegiance or mutual association
shortDefinitions: denoting organization or place which bears relationship to another of common origin or allegiance
